channel.title: Differentials
channel.description:
Hey there :)
I'm having a bit of difficulty with a question involving the use of differentials, and would be grateful if someone could help. The question is as follows:
[i]In a breeder reactor, plutonium-239 is produced from uranium-238 at a constant rate, but it decays at a rate proportional to the amount of plutonium-239 present. The half-life of plutonium-239 is estimated as 24 000 years. If plutonium-239 is produced at a rate of 1 microgram per minute, solve the differential equation to find the amount present at any time after the reactor begins operation[/i]
So pretty much: Plutonium-239 is produced at a rate of (1/1000000)g min[sup]-1[/sup] It also has a half life of 24000 years (so in 24000 years, 1g of Plutonium-239 will decay to 0.5 g)
Thanks in advance for any help.
- Adam

item.title: Differentials
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Hmm, a toughy indeed. Well you can start with the general differential equation for radioactive decay:

dN/dt = -λN

Where N is the amount of of the radioactive substance, dN/dt is the number of decays per second, and λ is the decay constant (ln(2) / half life). The general solution for this differential equation is pretty straight forward (N(t) = N[sub]o[/sub]e[sup]-λt[/sup]), but we need N[sub]o[/sub] to be a function of time, not just constant.

N[sub]o/sub = (6 x 10[sup]-7[/sup] g/s) * t
(Note, I just converted your term a tad)

Forgive me if this is completely wrong…
N(t) = N[sub]o/sube[sup]-λt[/sup]

dN/dt = (6 x 10-7 g/s)e[sup]-λt[/sup] + ((6 x 10-7 g/s) * t)(-λe[sup]-λt[/sup])
dN/dt = [(6 x 10-7 g/s)e[sup]-λt[/sup]] * (1 + -λt)
dN/dt = (N/t) * (1 + -λt)

That’s as far as I can go with what I remember. Its been a while since I’ve done differential equations, and I don’t remember anything like this - so chances are I’m completely off. Typically I don’t post if I’m not really sure about my answer, but perhaps something I did might help.

Read full topic
